question:
Who propounded the concept of 'Rule of Law'?

SSC MTS 11/09/2023 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The concept of 'Rule of Law' was propounded by A.V. Dicey, a British jurist and constitutional theorist.
  • He introduced the idea in his book “Introduction to the Study of the Law of the Constitution” published in 1885.
  • According to Dicey, the Rule of Law has three main principles:
    1. Supremacy of law – No one is above the law.
    2. Equality before the law – Every person is subject to the same law.
    3. Predominance of legal spirit – Rights are secured by the decisions of courts.

Additional Information:

  • The Rule of Law is a fundamental principle in British constitutional law.
  • It has been adopted into Indian constitutional framework, especially under Article 14, which guarantees equality before the law and equal protection of laws.
  • A.V. Dicey’s theory strongly opposes arbitrary power.

question:
In which of the following years was the Child Marriage Restraint Act passed?

SSC MTS 11/09/2023 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The Child Marriage Restraint Act was passed in the year 1929.
  • It is also popularly known as the Sarda Act, named after Harbilas Sarda, who introduced the bill in the British Indian Legislative Council.
  • This was the first social reform law in India to set a minimum legal age for marriage:
    • 14 years for girls
    • 18 years for boys
  • The Act aimed to curb the practice of child marriage, which was prevalent in Indian society at that time.

Additional Information:

  • The Act came into force in 1930.
  • Later amendments raised the legal age of marriage:
    • In 1978, it was revised to 18 years for girls and 21 years for boys.
  • The law laid the foundation for modern child protection and women’s rights legislation in India.

question:
Who described the Indian federal system as a bargaining federalism?

SSC CHSL 07/08/2023 (4th shift)
solution:
• The term “Bargaining Federalism” in the context of the Indian federal system was coined by Morris Jones, a British political scientist.
  • He used this term to describe how centre-state relations in India are shaped through continuous negotiation and compromise rather than rigid division of powers.
  • Unlike classical federal systems, India’s model is flexible, and power dynamics often shift depending on political conditions.
  • This reflects a negotiated balance rather than a strictly legalistic division of authority.

Additional Information:

  • Granville Austin described Indian federalism as “cooperative federalism”.
  • KC Wheare had argued that India’s Constitution is “quasi-federal” due to its strong central features.
  • Ivor Jennings stated that India is a unitary state with subsidiary federal features.

question:
‘The Constitution of free India must be framed, without outside interference by a constituent assembly elected on the basis of adult franchise’. Who made this statement?

SSC CHSL 08/08/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The statement “The Constitution of free India must be framed, without outside interference by a constituent assembly elected on the basis of adult franchise” was made by Jawaharlal Nehru.
  • This reflects Nehru’s strong belief in democratic values and the right of Indians to decide their own political future.
  • He emphasized that only a Constituent Assembly elected by adult suffrage could legitimately frame the Constitution of independent India.
  • Nehru made this statement in the backdrop of rising national demand for complete independence and self-governance.

Additional Information:

  • Jawaharlal Nehru was the Chairman of the Union Constitution Committee in the Constituent Assembly.
  • He moved the historic ‘Objectives Resolution’ in December 1946, which laid the ideological foundation of the Constitution.
  • The Constituent Assembly of India first met on 9 December 1946, and the Constitution was finally adopted on 26 November 1949.

question:
As per the responsibilities defined in National Food Security Act, 2013, which of the following is a responsibility of the state/UT government?

SSC CHSL 08/08/2023 (4th shift)
option_1: Transportation of foodgrains up to designated depots in each state/UT
option_2: Allocation of required foodgrains to states/UTS
option_3: Delivery of foodgrains from designated FCI godowns
option_4: Identification of eligible households
solution:
• Under the National Food Security Act (NFSA), 2013, the responsibility of identifying eligible households lies with the State/UT governments.
  • The Act empowers states/UTs to identify beneficiaries under two categories:
    • Priority Households
    • Antyodaya Anna Yojana (AAY) households
  • These households are entitled to 5 kg of subsidized foodgrains per person per month, while AAY households get 35 kg per household per month.
  • The Central Government is responsible for procurement, allocation, and transportation of foodgrains up to the state depots.

Additional Information:

  • The Food Corporation of India (FCI) manages procurement and distribution on behalf of the Central Government.
  • NFSA covers up to 75% of rural and 50% of urban population.
  • The Act also includes provisions for grievance redressal, food security allowance, and nutritional support for women and children.

question:
Justice Indu Malhotra penned a dissenting opinion in which of the following landmark judgements?

SSC CGL 19/07/2023 (3rd shift)
option_2: Preamble part of the Constitution
option_3: Entry of women to Sabarimala
option_4: Land reforms in India
solution:
• Justice Indu Malhotra gave a dissenting opinion in the Sabarimala temple case.
  • The case pertained to the entry of women of menstruating age (10–50 years) into the Sabarimala temple in Kerala.
  • In 2018, a five-judge Constitution Bench of the Supreme Court ruled by a 4:1 majority that the ban was unconstitutional, violating Article 14 (equality) and Article 25 (freedom of religion).
  • Justice Malhotra was the sole dissenter, stating that courts should not interfere in matters of essential religious practices of a faith group.

Additional Information:

  • Justice Malhotra was the first woman judge to be directly elevated to the Supreme Court from the Bar.
  • She emphasized that allowing courts to determine essential religious practices could lead to the erosion of religious freedom under Article 25.
  • The majority opinion was authored by Chief Justice Dipak Misra, with concurring opinions from Justices Rohinton Nariman, A.M. Khanwilkar, and D.Y. Chandrachud.

question:
The Taxation Laws (Amendment) Act, 2021, amends the Income Tax Act of ________.

Higher Secondary 27/06/2023 (Shift- 3)
solution:
• The Taxation Laws (Amendment) Act, 2021 was enacted to amend the Income Tax Act of 1961.
  • The Act was primarily introduced to remove the retrospective tax provisions that were introduced in 2012.
  • It nullified certain retrospective amendments related to the indirect transfer of Indian assets made by foreign companies.
  • This step was taken to boost investor confidence and resolve long-standing tax disputes involving companies like Vodafone and Cairn Energy.

Additional Information:

  • The Income Tax Act, 1961 is the main legislation governing income tax in India.
  • The 2021 amendment ensured that no tax demand shall be raised for any indirect transfer of Indian assets before May 28, 2012, if certain conditions are met.
  • Refunds were also proposed to be issued in such cases, without payment of interest.

question:
The Constitution (One Hundred and Twenty Seventh Amendment) Bill, 2021, was introduced in the Lok Sabha by the ______ in August 2021.

Higher Secondary 28/06/2023 (Shift- 2)
option_1: Minister of Social Justice and Empowerment
option_2: Minister of Minority Affairs
option_3: Minister of Tribal Affairs
option_4: Minister of Rural Development
solution:
• The Constitution (One Hundred and Twenty-Seventh Amendment) Bill, 2021 was introduced in the Lok Sabha on 9 August 2021 by Dr. Virendra Kumar, the Union Minister for Social Justice and Empowerment.
  • The primary objective of this amendment was to restore the power of State governments to identify and maintain their own list of Socially and Educationally Backward Classes (SEBCs), commonly referred to as Other Backward Classes (OBCs).
  • This move was necessitated by the Supreme Court's interpretation of the 102nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 2018, which was perceived to have curtailed the States' authority in this regard.
  • The 127th Amendment Bill was passed unanimously by both Houses of Parliament and subsequently received Presidential assent on 18 August 2021, becoming the 105th Constitutional Amendment Act, 2021.

Additional Information:

  • The amendment specifically modifies Articles 338B, 342A, and 366 of the Constitution to clarify that States and Union Territories have the authority to prepare and maintain their own list of SEBCs, separate from the Central List.
  • This legislative change was significant in upholding the federal structure of India, ensuring that States retain their autonomy in matters concerning the identification of backward classes for the purpose of reservation and other benefits.

question:
When were the general elections to the Legislative Assembly of the National Capital Territory held for the first time?

Matric Level 27/06/2023 (Shift- 2)
solution:
• The first general elections to the Legislative Assembly of the National Capital Territory (NCT) of Delhi were held on 6 November 1993 .
  • These elections were conducted following the 69th Constitutional Amendment Act, 1991, which granted Delhi a legislative assembly and a council of ministers, thereby providing it with a special status among Union Territories .
  • In this inaugural election, the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) secured a majority by winning 49 out of 70 seats, and Madan Lal Khurana became the first Chief Minister of the re-established Delhi Legislative Assembly .

Additional Information:

  • Prior to this, Delhi had a legislative assembly in 1952, which was later abolished in 1956 when Delhi became a Union Territory under the direct administration of the President of India.
  • From 1966 to 1990, Delhi was governed by the Delhi Metropolitan Council, which had limited advisory powers and no legislative authority .
  • The re-establishment of the Delhi Legislative Assembly in 1993 marked a significant step towards providing Delhi with a more autonomous and representative form of governance.

question:
Offences for which the police can arrest a person without an order from the court are called _________.

SSC MTS 02/05/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• Cognizable offences are those for which the police can arrest a person without prior approval or order from a magistrate.
  • These offences are generally of a serious nature, such as murder, rape, kidnapping, theft, etc.
  • The police can also start an investigation in such cases without the court's permission.
  • These are defined under the Criminal Procedure Code (CrPC), 1973, primarily in Section 2(c).

Additional Information:

  • In contrast, Non-cognizable offences (like defamation or public nuisance) require prior approval from a magistrate for arrest or investigation.
  • Cognizable offences are usually punishable with imprisonment of 3 years or more.
  • The classification ensures a faster response by law enforcement in serious cases.

question:
Which act has been amended by the Supreme Court of India to provide equal rights to daughters in their ancestral property ?

SSC MTS 17/05/2023 (Morning)
option_1: The Contempt of Courts Act
solution:
• The Supreme Court of India has interpreted the Hindu Succession Act to provide equal rights to daughters in their ancestral property.
  • The Hindu Succession Act, 1956 governs the inheritance rights among Hindus, including Buddhists, Jains, and Sikhs.
  • In 2005, the Act was amended to grant daughters the same rights as sons in ancestral property.
  • In the landmark judgment of Vineeta Sharma v. Rakesh Sharma (2020), the Supreme Court clarified that:
    • Daughters have equal coparcenary rights by birth, regardless of whether the father was alive at the time of the 2005 amendment.
    • This right is retrospective, ensuring daughters born before 2005 are also entitled to equal inheritance.

Additional Information:

  • The amendment to Section 6 of the Hindu Succession Act ensures that daughters are coparceners in the Hindu Undivided Family (HUF), just like sons.
  • This change aims to eliminate gender discrimination in property rights and uphold the constitutional guarantee of equality under Article 14.
  • The Supreme Court's interpretation reinforces the principle that inheritance rights are determined by birth, not by gender or the date of birth.

question:
The Union Finance Ministry issued a notification amending the Electoral Bonds Scheme to allow the sale of electoral bonds for extra _______ days in the year of general elections to the Legislative Assembly of States and UTs with legislature.

SSC MTS 16/06/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The Union Finance Ministry issued a notification amending the Electoral Bonds Scheme to allow the sale of electoral bonds for an additional 15 days in the year of general elections to the Legislative Assembly of States and Union Territories with legislature.
  • Prior to this amendment, electoral bonds were available for purchase for a period of 10 days each in January, April, July, and October. Additionally, an extra 30-day period was allowed in a Lok Sabha election year.
  • The amendment, notified on November 7, 2022, introduced an extra 15-day window in years when Assembly elections are held, thereby increasing the total sale days from 70 to 85 in such years .

Additional Information:

  • The Electoral Bonds Scheme, introduced in 2018, was designed to provide a transparent method for political funding by allowing individuals and entities to purchase bonds from authorized banks and donate them to political parties.
  • However, the scheme faced criticism for promoting anonymity in political donations, as the identity of donors was not disclosed to the public.
  • On February 15, 2024, the Supreme Court of India declared the Electoral Bonds Scheme unconstitutional, stating that it violated the right to information of voters under Article 19(1)(a) of the Constitution .

question:
In which year was the Dowry Prohibition Act passed in India?

SSC CHSL 10/03/2023 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The Dowry Prohibition Act was passed in 1961 to prohibit the giving or receiving of dowry in India.
  • This Act applies to people of all religions in India.
  • Under the Act, dowry is defined as any property or valuable security given directly or indirectly:
    • by one party to a marriage to the other party, or
    • by the parents of either party to a marriage or by any other person,
    • before, during, or after the marriage.
  • The Act made demanding, giving, or taking dowry a punishable offense with imprisonment and fines.

Additional Information:

  • The Act was later amended in 1984 and 1986 to make the provisions stricter.
  • Section 498A of the Indian Penal Code was also added in 1983 to deal with cruelty related to dowry demands.
  • Despite legal provisions, dowry-related harassment and deaths remain a serious social issue in India.

question:
In which year was the Arms Act passed in India?

SSC CHSL 10/03/2023 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The Arms Act was passed in 1959 in India.
  • Its main objective was to regulate the acquisition, possession, manufacture, sale, and transfer of arms and ammunition.
  • The Act replaced the colonial-era Indian Arms Act of 1878, which was implemented by the British to disarm Indians after the Revolt of 1857.
  • Under the 1959 Act, civilian ownership of firearms requires a valid license issued by the competent authority.
  • It categorizes weapons into Prohibited Bore (PB) and Non-Prohibited Bore (NPB).

Additional Information:

  • The Rules under the Arms Act were framed in 1962, known as the Arms Rules, 1962.
  • The Act empowers the government to regulate the use and possession of weapons to ensure public safety and national security.
  • Violations of the Act can result in severe penalties, including imprisonment and fines.

question:
In which year was the Special Marriage Act passed in India?

SSC CHSL 16/03/2023 (4th Shift)
solution:
• The Special Marriage Act was passed in 1954 in India.
  • It provides a legal framework for the solemnization and registration of marriages irrespective of the religion or faith of the parties involved.
  • The Act allows inter-religious and inter-caste marriages without requiring conversion or religious customs.
  • It applies to all Indian citizens, whether residing in India or abroad.
  • Marriages under this Act are civil marriages, and they require notice, objections, and registration as specified in the Act.

Additional Information:

  • The Act is administered by the Marriage Officer, who ensures legal procedures are followed.
  • A 30-day public notice is mandatory before solemnization.
  • It upholds secularism and provides legal protection for interfaith and inter-caste couples.
  • The Special Marriage Act is a key legislation for ensuring freedom of choice in marriage and protecting individual rights.

question:
In India, according to the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016, the process of insolvency resolution for companies should be completed in how many days?

SSC CGL Tier II (06/03/2023)
solution:
• As per the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (IBC), 2016, the Corporate Insolvency Resolution Process (CIRP) for companies must be completed within 180 days.
  • However, this period can be extended by 90 days if the adjudicating authority (NCLT) deems it necessary, taking the maximum total to 270 days.
  • The aim is to ensure time-bound resolution of corporate insolvency to maximize asset value and protect creditor interests.
  • The process is initiated when a default occurs, and a Resolution Professional (RP) is appointed to manage the affairs of the company during the process.

Additional Information:

  • The IBC came into force in December 2016 to consolidate and amend laws relating to reorganization and insolvency.
  • The National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT) is the adjudicating authority for companies under IBC.
  • In 2019, an amendment introduced a maximum time limit of 330 days, including all litigation and judicial processes.

question:
What are the two most essential rights of a democracy?

SSC CGL 03/12/2022 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• In a democracy, the two most essential rights are Equality and Freedom.
  • Equality ensures that every citizen is treated equally before the law, without discrimination based on religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth (Article 14).
  • Freedom guarantees various civil liberties like:
    • Freedom of speech and expression
    • Freedom to assemble peacefully
    • Freedom to form associations
    • Freedom to move freely and reside anywhere in the country
    • Freedom to practice any profession (Article 19)
  • These rights empower citizens to participate freely in the democratic process and express their opinions without fear.

Additional Information:

  • These rights are part of the Fundamental Rights enshrined in Part III of the Indian Constitution.
  • They form the core values of a democratic society and are enforceable by courts.
  • Dr. B.R. Ambedkar referred to Fundamental Rights as the heart and soul of the Constitution.

question:
In which year was the Indian Parliamentary Group established?

SSC CGL 05/12/2022 (4th Shift)
solution:
• The Indian Parliamentary Group (IPG) was established in the year 1949.
  • It is a non-official and non-political body of Members of Parliament (MPs).
  • The group was founded with the aim to promote contact and exchange of ideas between Indian Parliamentarians and their counterparts in other countries.
  • The Speaker of the Lok Sabha is the ex-officio President of the group.
  • Members of both the Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha can become members of the IPG.

Additional Information:

  • The IPG serves as a link between the Indian Parliament and international parliamentary bodies, especially the Inter-Parliamentary Union (IPU) and the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association (CPA).
  • It plays a key role in parliamentary diplomacy, exchange visits, and fostering international goodwill.

question:
If the State government dissolves the Panchayati Raj Institutions before the end of their five-year term, fresh elections should ordinarily be held within _____.

SSC CGL 12/12/2022 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• According to Article 243E(3) of the Indian Constitution, if the Panchayati Raj Institutions (PRIs) are dissolved before the completion of their five-year term, then fresh elections must be held within six months from the date of dissolution.
  • This provision ensures the continuity of local self-governance and avoids administrative vacuum at the grassroots level.
  • The newly elected Panchayat will serve for the remainder of the five-year term if the dissolution occurs prematurely.

Additional Information:

  • The 73rd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1992 introduced the Panchayati Raj system in India.
  • It provides for a three-tier system:
    • Gram Panchayat (village level)
    • Panchayat Samiti (block level)
    • Zila Parishad (district level)
  • Article 243E mandates regular elections every five years, and elections must be conducted even in cases of premature dissolution.

question:
Which freedom is considered as the ‘Hallmark of Democracy’?

SSC CGL 13/12/2022 (2nd Shift)
option_2: Right to freedom of religion
option_4: Freedom of speech and expression
solution:
• The Freedom of speech and expression is widely regarded as the ‘Hallmark of Democracy’, not the right to freedom of religion.
  • It enables citizens to express their opinions, criticize the government, and participate actively in public discourse, which is essential for the functioning of a democratic system.
  • This right is guaranteed under Article 19(1)(a) of the Indian Constitution.

Therefore, the correct answer should be: (d) Freedom of speech and expression, not (b).

question:
The detention of a person cannot exceed ________ unless an advisory board consisting of judges of a High Court reports sufficient cause for extended detention.

SSC CPO 11/11/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• Under Article 22(4) of the Indian Constitution, a person detained under preventive detention cannot be held for more than three months unless:
    • An Advisory Board, consisting of judges of a High Court, reviews the case and reports sufficient cause for extended detention.
  • This provision balances national security and individual liberty, ensuring that preventive detention is not misused.
  • If no such Advisory Board recommendation is made, the maximum permissible detention period is three months.

Additional Information:

  • The Advisory Board must consist of at least three judges of a High Court.
  • If the Board permits, detention can be extended beyond three months, but even that must follow constitutional and legal safeguards.
  • Preventive detention laws in India include the National Security Act (NSA), COFEPOSA, etc.

question:
When was the National Emergency declared for the first time under Article 352 ?

SSC CPO 11/11/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The first National Emergency under Article 352 of the Indian Constitution was declared in the year 1962, due to the India-China war.
  • It remained in force from 26 October 1962 to 10 January 1968, making it the longest-lasting National Emergency in India's history.
  • Article 352 allows the President to declare a National Emergency in case of:
    • War
    • External aggression
    • Armed rebellion

Additional Information:

  • During a National Emergency:
    • The Centre gains overriding powers over the states.
    • Fundamental Rights under Article 19 are automatically suspended.
    • The Lok Sabha’s tenure can be extended by 1 year at a time.
  • India has seen three National Emergencies: in 1962, 1971, and 1975.

question:
How many religious communities are notified as minorities by the Government of India?

Graduate Level 01/08/2022 (Shift- 4)
solution:
• The Government of India has officially notified six religious communities as minorities under Section 2(c) of the National Commission for Minorities Act, 1992.
  • These six communities are:
    1. Muslims
    2. Christians
    3. Sikhs
    4. Buddhists
    5. Parsis (Zoroastrians)
    6. Jains
  • Initially, five religious communities—Muslims, Christians, Sikhs, Buddhists, and Parsis—were notified as minority communities by the Union Government. Subsequently, in 2014, the Jain community was also added to this list.

Additional Information:

  • These communities are recognized as minorities at the national level across India. However, the minority status of religious and linguistic communities can also be determined at the state level, depending on the demographic composition of each state.
  • The National Commission for Minorities (NCM), established under the National Commission for Minorities Act, 1992, is responsible for safeguarding and protecting the interests of these minority communities.

question:
In which year was the National Youth Policy launched by the Government of India ?

Higher Secondary 05/08/2022 (Shift- 2)
solution:
• The National Youth Policy (NYP) 2014 was officially launched by the Government of India on 21 February 2014. This policy replaced the earlier NYP of 2003.
  • The NYP 2014 aims to empower the youth of India to achieve their full potential and, through them, enable India to find its rightful place in the community of nations. It focuses on youth aged 15 to 29 years, who constitute approximately 5% of India's population.

Additional Information:

  • The policy identifies five key objectives and 11 priority areas, including:
    • Education
    • Employment and Skill Development
    • Entrepreneurship
    • Health and Healthy Lifestyle
    • Sports
    • Promotion of Social Values
    • Community Engagement
    • Participation in Politics and Governance
    • Youth Engagement
    • Inclusion
    • Social Justice
  • The NYP 2014 serves as a guiding document for various stakeholders, including government ministries, departments, and non-governmental organizations, to implement youth-centric programs and initiatives.

question:
Which freedom fighter abolished the Zamindari System in Uttar Pradesh and was elected as the Home Minister in 1955?

SSC MTS 26/07/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Govind Ballabh Pant.
  • Govind Ballabh Pant was a prominent freedom fighter and an influential leader in the Indian National Congress.
  • After independence, he became the first Chief Minister of Uttar Pradesh.
  • During his tenure, he played a major role in abolishing the Zamindari System in Uttar Pradesh to eliminate feudal land ownership and promote agrarian reform.
  • In 1955, he was appointed as the Union Home Minister of India.

Additional Information:

  • As Home Minister, Pant was known for:
    • Promoting Hindi as the official language.
    • Reorganizing Indian states on a linguistic basis.
  • He was awarded the Bharat Ratna in 1957, India’s highest civilian award.
  • His work laid the foundation for land reform and administrative modernization in post-independence India.

question:
As per the coding convention of India Census, how many digit code is used for showing state code?

SSC CHSL 03/06/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• According to the coding convention of the Census of India, each state and union territory is assigned a 2-digit code.
  • This 2-digit state code is used consistently in census data, statistical records, and administrative documentation to uniquely identify states/UTs.
  • For example:
    • 01 – Jammu & Kashmir
    • 09 – Uttar Pradesh
    • 27 – Maharashtra

Additional Information:

  • Along with the 2-digit state code, a 4-digit district code and a 6-digit sub-district code are also used in the census hierarchy.
  • This system helps in systematic classification and retrieval of demographic data across administrative levels.
  • These codes are standardized and remain consistent across different government departments.

question:
On which day was the National Emblem of India adopted ?

SSC CGL 11/04/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• The National Emblem of India was officially adopted on 26th January 1950, the day when India became a Republic.
  • It is an adaptation of the Lion Capital of Ashoka at Sarnath, which was originally erected around 250 BCE.
  • The emblem features four Asiatic lions standing back to back, but only three are visible at a time.
  • It symbolizes power, courage, pride, and confidence.

Additional Information:

  • The base of the emblem includes:
    • A horse and a bull separated by a wheel (Ashoka Chakra).
    • The motto "Satyameva Jayate" (Truth Alone Triumphs) written in Devanagari script, taken from the Mundaka Upanishad.
  • The emblem is used on official documents, currency, government buildings, and is the seal of the Government of India.

question:
The Right of Children to Free and Compulsory Education Act 2009 is an Act of Parliament which came into force in:

SSC CGL 11/04/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• The Right of Children to Free and Compulsory Education Act, commonly known as the RTE Act, was passed by the Parliament of India in 2009, but it came into force on 1st April 2010.
  • This Act makes education a fundamental right for children aged 6 to 14 years, under Article 21A of the Indian Constitution.
  • It mandates that every child has the right to full-time elementary education of satisfactory and equitable quality in a formal school.

Additional Information:

  • The RTE Act requires:
    • Free and compulsory education for all children aged 6–14.
    • 25% reservation in private schools for children from disadvantaged sections.
    • Prohibition of capitation fee, screening procedure, physical punishment, and mental harassment.
    • Ensures pupil-teacher ratio, infrastructure norms, and qualified teachers.

question:
In which of the following years was an Act enacted to provide for the reorganisation of the states of India and for matters connected therewith?

SSC CGL 12/04/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The States Reorganisation Act was enacted in the year 1956.
  • It came into effect on 1st November 1956 and was a major reform in the political map of India.
  • The Act was based on the recommendations of the States Reorganisation Commission (SRC), which was constituted in 1953 under the chairmanship of Fazl Ali.
  • The main objective was to reorganize Indian states on linguistic lines to improve administrative convenience and reflect cultural identities.

Additional Information:

  • As a result of this Act:
    • The number of states was reduced and reorganized into 14 states and 6 union territories.
    • Several boundaries were redrawn, and some new states were formed by merging or splitting existing ones.
  • The Seventh Constitutional Amendment Act, 1956 was passed to support the changes made by the States Reorganisation Act.

question:
Which of the following Acts was passed by the Government of India to inquire into allegations of corruption against certain public functionaries?

SSC MTS 11/10/2021 (Afternoon)
option_2: Prevention of Money Laundering Act
option_3: Central Vigilance Commission Act
option_4: The Lokpal and Lokayukta Act
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) The Lokpal and Lokayukta Act.
  • This Act was passed by the Parliament of India in 2013 and came into effect on 16 January 2014.
  • Its purpose is to inquire into allegations of corruption against certain public functionaries, including:
    • The Prime Minister (with conditions),
    • Ministers,
    • Members of Parliament, and
    • Government officials.

Additional Information:

  • The Act provides for:
    • Establishment of Lokpal at the central level and Lokayuktas at the state level.
    • Lokpal consists of a Chairperson and up to 8 members, of whom 50% must be judicial members.
    • It has the power to conduct inquiries, investigations, and initiate prosecution against public servants.

question:
The Indian Forest Act 1927 was enacted after repealing which of the following Indian forest acts?

SSC CGL 23/08/2021 (Morning)
solution:
• The Indian Forest Act, 1927 was enacted by the British Government to consolidate the laws relating to forests, forest produce, and the duty on timber.
  • It repealed the Indian Forest Act, 1878, which was the earlier comprehensive legislation on forest regulation.
  • The 1927 Act incorporated and updated provisions from both the Indian Forest Act, 1865 and the Indian Forest Act, 1878.

Key Provisions of the 1927 Act:

  • It classifies forests into Reserved Forests, Protected Forests, and Village Forests.
  • It defines forest produce and provides detailed rules on the regulation of transit of forest produce.
  • It grants the government the power to declare forests as reserved or protected and restrict activities like logging, grazing, and hunting.

Additional Information:

  • The Indian Forest Act, 1927 is still in effect (with amendments) in many states.
  • Several recent forest and environment-related laws (like the Forest Rights Act, 2006) build upon the foundations laid by this Act.

question:
One-third of the members of the Vidhan Parishad retire every ______ years.

SSC CHSL 06/08/2021 (Morning)
solution:
• The Vidhan Parishad (Legislative Council) is the Upper House in the State Legislature (wherever applicable).
  • It is a permanent body, not subject to dissolution.
  • However, one-third (1/3) of its members retire every two years, similar to the Rajya Sabha at the national level.
  • This system ensures continuity in the functioning of the house.

Additional Information:

  • Members of the Vidhan Parishad are elected for a term of 6 years.
  • Elections are held periodically to fill the seats of retiring members.
  • Only a few Indian states have a Legislative Council, including Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Maharashtra, Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, and Telangana.

question:
Which was the first part of India to hold an election based on universal adult franchise ?

SSC CHSL 09/08/2021 (Morning)
solution:
• The first part of India to hold an election based on universal adult franchise was Manipur.
  • This historic election took place in 1948, even before the adoption of the Indian Constitution in 1950.
  • Universal adult franchise means that all adult citizens, regardless of caste, gender, religion, or wealth, have the right to vote.

Additional Information:

  • Manipur was a princely state with its own constitution and legislative setup at that time.
  • The elections were held to form the Manipur State Assembly under the Manipur State Constitution Act, 1947.
  • This set a precedent for the democratic process in post-independence India.

question:
On the night of ______ 1975, Indira Gandhi recommended the imposition of Emergency to president Fakhruddin Ali Ahmed.

SSC CPO 23/11/2020 (Evening)
solution:
• On the night of 25th June 1975, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi recommended the imposition of National Emergency to the then President Fakhruddin Ali Ahmed.
  • The Emergency was officially declared on 26th June 1975 under Article 352 of the Constitution, citing internal disturbance.
  • It marked one of the most controversial periods in Indian democracy, lasting 21 months until 21 March 1977.

Additional Information:

  • During the Emergency:
    • Civil liberties were suspended.
    • Press censorship was imposed.
    • Many opposition leaders were arrested.
  • It is often criticized for misuse of constitutional powers and suppression of dissent.
  • This period played a crucial role in shaping future constitutional safeguards like the 44th Amendment Act, 1978, which introduced checks on emergency powers.

question:
Which of the following is the expanded form of the abbreviation 'Rep.' used in the text of the Constitution of India?

SSC CGL 20/08/2021 (Evening)
solution:
• In the text of the Constitution of India, the abbreviation 'Rep.' stands for "Repealed".
  • It is used to indicate that a particular provision, article, or clause has been formally removed or annulled from the Constitution by a subsequent amendment or law.

Additional Information:

  • For example, when certain articles or schedules become redundant or obsolete, they are repealed by Parliament through a constitutional amendment.
  • In the official publications of the Constitution, such repealed provisions are marked with the abbreviation ‘Rep.’, usually followed by a footnote indicating the amending Act or order.

question:
______ is a set of norms and guidelines to be followed by the political parties and contesting candidates during election time.

SSC CHSL 19/04/2021 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The correct answer is (c) Code of Conduct.
  • The Model Code of Conduct (MCC) is a set of norms and guidelines issued by the Election Commission of India (ECI).
  • It is meant to regulate the behavior of political parties and candidates during the election period to ensure free and fair elections.
  • It comes into effect from the date the election schedule is announced by the Election Commission and remains in force until the completion of the election process.

Key Features of the Code of Conduct:

  • No use of hate speech or personal attacks.
  • No bribing or intimidation of voters.
  • Restriction on use of government resources for campaigning.
  • Ministers should not announce new schemes or projects during this period.

Additional Information:

  • Though not legally binding, violating the code can result in warnings, censure, or even criminal charges under existing laws.
  • The MCC plays a crucial role in upholding the integrity and neutrality of the electoral process.

question:
In 1977, who became then President of the Janata Party, which formed a coalition government at the centre with Morarji Desai as the Prime Minister?

SSC CGL 18/08/2021 (Afternoon)
solution:
• In 1977, after the Emergency period, the Janata Party emerged as a coalition of opposition parties to challenge the Congress.
  • The Janata Party won the Lok Sabha elections held in March 1977, leading to the formation of a non-Congress government for the first time at the Centre.
  • Morarji Desai became the Prime Minister, and Chandra Shekhar was appointed as the President of the Janata Party.

Additional Information:

  • Chandra Shekhar was known as a socialist leader and had earlier been a member of the Indian National Congress.
  • He later became the Prime Minister of India in 1990 for a brief period.
  • The Janata Party included leaders like Jayaprakash Narayan, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, Charan Singh, and George Fernandes.
